./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Introduction

Software engineering principles, from Robert C. Martin's book
Clean Code,
adapted for TypeScript. This is not a style guide. It's a guide to producing
readable, reusable, and refactorable software in TypeScript.
Not every principle herein has to be strictly followed, and even fewer will be
universally agreed upon. These are guidelines and nothing more, but they are
ones codified over many years of collective experience by the authors of
Clean Code.
Our craft of software engineering is just a bit over 50 years old, and we are
still learning a lot. When software architecture is as old as architecture
itself, maybe then we will have harder rules to follow. For now, let these
guidelines serve as a touchstone by which to assess the quality of the
TypeScript code that you and your team produce.
One more thing: knowing these won't immediately make you a better software
developer, and working with them for many years doesn't mean you won't make
mistakes. Every piece of code starts as a first draft, like wet clay getting
shaped into its final form. Finally, we chisel away the imperfections when
we review it with our peers. Don't beat yourself up for first drafts that need
improvement. Beat up the code instead!

TRANSLATIONS.html.title: Translations
TRANSLATIONS.html.body:
Translations
This is also available in other languages:

 Brazilian Portuguese: vitorfreitas/clean-code-typescript

beginor/clean-code-typescript
pipiliang/clean-code-typescript


 French: ralflorent/clean-code-typescript
 German: mheob/clean-code-typescript
 Japanese: MSakamaki/clean-code-typescript
 Korean: 738/clean-code-typescript
 Russian: Real001/clean-code-typescript
 Spanish: JoseDeFreitas/clean-code-typescript
 Turkish: ozanhonamlioglu/clean-code-typescript
 Vietnamese: hoangsetup/clean-code-typescript

References will be added once translations are completed.Check this discussion for more details and progress.
You can make an indispensable contribution to Clean Code community by translating this to your language.
